pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.1.2: At that time Venerable Dabba the Mallian had realized perfection at the age of seven.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.1.3: He had realized all there is to be realized by a disciple
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.1.4: and had nothing further to do.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.1.5: While he was in seclusion he reflected on this,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.1.9: and he thought, “How may I be of service to the Sangha?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.1.11: Perhaps I could assign dwellings for the Sangha and designate the meals?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.2.1: In the evening Dabba came out of seclusion and approached the Buddha. He bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.2.3: “Venerable Sir, while I was in seclusion I reflected that I’ve attained all that can be attained by a disciple, and I was wondering how I might be of service to the Sangha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.2.5: I could assign dwellings for the Sangha and designate the meals.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.2: “Monks, the Sangha should appoint Dabba the Mallian as the assigner of dwellings and the designator of meals.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.3: And he should be appointed like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.5: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.6: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.7: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should appoint Venerable Dabba the Mallian as assigner of dwellings and designator of meals.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.9: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.10: The Sangha appoints Venerable Dabba the Mallian as assigner of dwellings and designator of meals.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.11: Any monk who approves of appointing Venerable Dabba the Mallian as assigner of dwellings and designator of meals should remain silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.12: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.13: The Sangha has appointed Venerable Dabba the Mallian as assigner of dwellings and designator of meals.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.3.14: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.1: Dabba assigned dwellings to the monks according to their character.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.2: He assigned dwellings in the same place to those monks who were experts on the discourses, thinking,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.4: And he did likewise for the experts on the Monastic Law, thinking,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.6: for the expounders of the Teaching, thinking,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.10: and for the gossips and the body-builders, thinking,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.11: “In this way even these venerables will be happy.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.12: When monks arrived at night, he entered the fire element and assigned dwellings with the help of that light.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.13: Monks even arrived late on purpose,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.14: hoping to see the marvel of Dabba’s supernormal powers.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.15: They would approach Dabba and say,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.19: They would intentionally suggest somewhere far away,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.20: “Please assign us a dwelling on the Vulture Peak,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.22: “… on Black Rock on the slope of Mount Isigili,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.23: “… in the Sattapaṇṇi Cave on the slope of Mount Vebhāra,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.24: “… in Cool Grove on the hill at the Snake’s Pool,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.30: “… in the deer park at Maddakucchi.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.31: Dabba then entered the fire element, and with his finger glowing, he walked in front of those monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.32: They followed closely behind him with the help of that light.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.33: And he would assign them dwellings:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.34: “This is the bed, this the bench, this the mattress, this the pillow, this the place for defecating, this the place for urinating, this the water for drinking, this the water for washing, this the walking stick;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.35: these are the Sangha’s agreements concerning the right time to enter and the right time to depart.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.4.36: Dabba then returned to the Bamboo Grove.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.5.1: At that time the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka were only newly ordained. They had little merit,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.5.2: and they obtained inferior dwellings and meals.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.5.3: The people of Rājagaha were keen to give specially prepared almsfood to the senior monks—ghee, oil, and special foods—
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.5.4: but to the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka they gave ordinary food of porridge and broken rice.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.5.5: After the meal, when they had returned from almsround, they asked the senior monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.5.6: “What did you get at the dining hall?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.5.8: “We got ghee, oil, and special curry.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.5.9: But the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.5.10: “We didn’t get anything except ordinary food of porridge and broken rice.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.1: At that time there was a householder who gave a regular meal of fine food to four monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.2: He made his offering in the dining hall together with his wives and children.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.3: Some of them offered rice, others curry, others oil, and others special foods.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.4: On one occasion the meal to be given by this householder on the following day had been designated to the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.5: Just then that householder went to the monastery on some business.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.6: He approached Dabba, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.7: Dabba then instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.8: After the talk, he asked Dabba,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.9: “Sir, who has been designated to receive tomorrow’s meal in our house?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.12: “Why should bad monks eat in our house?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.13: After returning to his house, he told a female slave,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.6.14: “For those who are coming for tomorrow’s meal, prepare seats at the gateway and serve them broken rice and porridge.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.1: The monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka said to each other,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.2: “Yesterday we were designated a meal from that householder who offers fine food.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.3: Tomorrow he’ll serve us together with his wives and children.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.4: Some of them will offer us rice, others curry, others oil, and others special foods.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.5: And because they were excited, they did not sleep properly that night.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.6: The following morning they robed up, took their bowls and robes, and went to the house of that householder.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.7: When the female slave saw them coming, she prepared seats at the gateway and said to them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.10: “The meal can’t be ready, since we’re given seats at the gateway.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.11: She then brought them broken rice and porridge, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.13: “But, Sister, we’ve come for the regular meal.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.15: But yesterday I was told by the head of the household to serve you like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.18: “Yesterday this householder came to the monastery and spoke with Dabba.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.19: Dabba must be responsible for this split between this householder and us.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.20: And because they were dejected, they did not eat as much as they had intended.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.7.21: After the meal they returned to the monastery, put their bowls and robes away, and squatted on their heels outside the monastery gateway, using their upper robe as a back-and-knee strap. They were silent and humiliated, their shoulders drooping and their heads down, glum and speechless.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.1: Just then the nun Mettiyā approached them and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.5: and a third time she said
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.7: but they still did not respond.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.10: “It’s because we’ve been badly treated by Dabba the Mallian, and you’re not taking an interest.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.12: “If you like, you could make the Buddha expel Dabba.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.13: “What should I do? How am I able to do that?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.15: ‘Venerable Sir, this isn’t proper or appropriate.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.16: There’s fear, distress, and oppression in this district, where none of these should exist.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.17: From where one would expect security, there’s insecurity.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.18: It’s as if water is burning.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.19: Venerable Dabba the Mallian has raped me.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.20: Saying, “Alright,” she approached the Buddha, bowed,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.8.21: and then repeated what she had been told to say.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned Dabba:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.2: “Dabba, do you remember doing as the nun Mettiyā says?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.5: a third time the Buddha asked
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.8: He then said, “Dabba, the Dabbas don’t give such evasive answers.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.9: If it was done by you, say so;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.10: if it wasn’t done by you, then say that.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.11: “Sir, since I was born I don’t recall having sexual intercourse even in a dream, much less when I was awake.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.13: “Well then, monks, expel the nun Mettiyā,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.14: and call these monks to account.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.15: The Buddha then got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.16: When the monks had expelled the nun Mettiyā,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.17: the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka said to them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.20: She was urged on by us, because we were angry, displeased, and aiming to make Dabba leave the monastic life.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.21: “But did you groundlessly charge Venerable Dabba with an offense entailing expulsion?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.23: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.24: “How can the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka groundlessly charge Venerable Dabba with an offense entailing expulsion?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.25: They rebuked those monks in many ways and then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.26: “Is it true, monks, that you groundlessly charged Dabba the Mallian with an offense entailing expulsion?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.29: “… Foolish men, how can you groundlessly charge Dabba with an offense entailing expulsion?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.30: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.31: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.32.1: ‘If a monk who is angry and displeased groundlessly charges a monk with an offense entailing expulsion, aiming to make him leave the monastic life,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8:1.9.33: and then after some time, whether he is questioned or not, it is clear that the legal issue is groundless, and he admits to his ill will, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”
